options: Take all 8 of the bloods yourself and complete a significant event form
Call the local paper to publicise the issue
Take blood only from patients who are acutely unwell and complete a significant event form
Ask the nurses to help you take blood from all 8 patients and complete a significant event form
Refuse to take any bloods and make a formal complaint to management
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor on a nephrology ward. The phlebotomist covering your ward is off-sick for the second week in a row. You had put blood forms out for 8 of the 20 patients on the ward and feel you neither have the time nor contractual obligation to perform routine phlebotomy.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Whilst doctors should not have to provide routine phlebotomy this is not an uncommon scenario.

The best response is to enlist help from other members of the team to ensure all the bloods are taken. Completing a significant event form can help make management aware of the problem and with time may change service provision. Taking the bloods by yourself may be admirable but it is better to try and share the workload if possible.

Rationing phlebotomy to patients who are acutely unwell involves a compromise in patient care, especially on a nephrology ward.

Refusing to take bloods as a protest shows an unprofessional approach as you are willing to let patient care suffer to make a point.

options: Fill in a clinical incident form about his high referral rate
Write an e-mail to the post-graduate dean
Do nothing but mark him down during the '360 degree' assessment

questions:
You are a GP registrar. There is currently a F2 doctor assigned to your practice. From seeing patients that he has already seen you become aware that he has a high referral rate and seems to organise unconventional management plans. As far as you are aware there have been no incidents of patients coming to any kind of harm.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
From the limited information presented a picture is painted of a trainee who is not necessarily dangerous but is having trouble managing patients in a primary care context.

As with other situational judgement questions, the best response is to speak directly with the doctor about your observations.

The next best person to deal with this is his trainer who may able to subtlety address relevant issues whilst doing the normal review of his cases.

If the trainer has persistent concerns about the doctor then it is his/her role to speak to the postgraduate dean, rather than yourself.

Although it is important to be honest when asked to assess a colleague you equally should try to help doctors who may be struggling in their current role.

options: Advise the patient to make another appointment if they wish to discuss things further
Contact social services
Contact the partner to arrange a mediation session with the partner and patient
Contact the police
Give the patient information on local domestic violence support groups and arrange a follow-up
questions:
A patient attends his GP with insomnia and anxiety. At the end of the consultation, he discloses that his partner is both physically and emotionally abusive. He has not told anyone before and does not wish to take things further.

There are no children in the house and he does not believe his partner is a risk to others. You believe the patient to have capacity.

What is the most appropriate next step?


Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
This case involves an adult who discloses domestic abuse but who does not wish for the disclosure to be taken further. In Good Medical Practice (2013), the GMC reiterates that all patients have the right to a confidential medical service. However, there are circumstances where disclosing information is justified in the public interest. In the case of domestic violence, for example, this information would need to be shared if there were children or a vulnerable adult at risk. However, this is not the case in this scenario. The adult patient has capacity and there are no other adults or children at risk. GMC guidance states that 'doctors should usually abide by the wishes of an adult patient who refuses consent to information being shared, even if that leaves them, but nobody else, at risk of harm'. The guidance also states, however, that doctors should give patients appropriate information and support them to get help. The most appropriate answer is, therefore, give the patient information on local domestic violence support groups and arrange a follow-up. Arranging a follow-up will allow you to provide further support and information to the patient if required.

The next most appropriate answer is advise the patient to make another appointment if they wish to discuss things further. This is not the best option as you have not given the patient information and support, as the GMC stipulates. The patient may not make a further appointment and therefore may not be given the resources they need. They may feel dismissed by this option. However, this option is better than the remaining options which all involve breaking confidentiality.

The next three options are all inappropriate as they involve breaking confidentiality. Of the three, contact the police is the least inappropriate as this would be the correct agency to contact if the patient did give you permission to take this further. It is a legal matter, rather than a matter for social services, as no children or vulnerable adults are involved.

Contact social services is incorrect both as this option involves breaking patient confidentiality and contacting the wrong services - there are no children or vulnerable adults involved in this scenario.

Contact the partner to arrange a mediation session with the partner and patient is the worst option. You are likely not qualified to lead a mediation session between the couple. More significantly, this option would involve both breaking patient confidentiality and it would potentially put your patient at risk, as their partner is now aware that they have disclosed the abuse. Whilst contacting the police or social services is breaking confidentiality, these options do not involve putting the patient at risk from their partner.

title: GMC: Confidentiality - Disclosures for the protection of patients and others
body:
This guidance covers disclosing information in adults; there is separate GMC guidance for children.

The GMC highlight the importance of a confidential medical service. However, sometimes patients are unable to protect themselves, and we may need to disclose personal information to protect their health and welfare.

I'm worried that my patient is at risk of harm abuse or neglect- Should I disclose?

1) Empower patients- make decisions about how to best move forward in partnership

2) If disclosure is required by law- You must disclose, but only the specific requested information, in the manner required by law. Inform your patient of disclosure (unless It would undermine the purpose)

3) Some disclosures are permitted but not required by law- these should have a legal basis

4) How you act will partly depend on whether this patient has capacity or lacks capacity:

Disclosure required by lawDisclosure not required by law
Has capacityYou must discloseRequires patient consent (if practicable)- ultimately the patient's decision unless non-disclosure puts others at risk of serious harm/death. If they refuse, find out why, inform them of the risks and refer to support groups
Lacks capacityYou must discloseYou must disclose to appropriate authority/person (unless not of overall benefit to the patient). Discuss with an experienced colleague and document if you think it's not in the patient's best interest

Can I share information to protect others/the public?

Confidentiality is in the public interest as it benefits society and individuals to seek medical care. However, this must be balanced with protecting and promoting the health of patients and the public.

Required by lawRequests for informationDisclosure not required by law
You must disclose e.g. infectious disease notification, provision of social and health care, preventing terrorism and investigation of road traffic accidents.Take these seriously if patients pose a risk of serious harm (e.g. violent or sex offenders), and for formal inquiries, inquests and reviewsEither patient must consent (unless not practicable) or must have a legal basis
If you have already decided to disclose the information, don't request consent, instead inform them of this intention, unless not safe or practicable.


Deciding if you will disclose regardless of if the patient consents:

1. Would non-disclosure put others at risk of death or serious harm? - this may justify disclosure e.g.
  • When a victim of violence doesn't want to inform the police, but the perpetrator still poses a significant risk to others, such as children in domestic violence.
  • If someone keeps driving despite being told they are not fit to drive
  • A patient has a serious communicable disease but refuses to disclose
  • A patient is working despite being unfit for work and this poses a serious risk to others

2. You should only disclose if you decide that the risk of not disclosing is so serious that it outweighs the patient and public interest in maintaining confidentiality.

Pro-confidentiality factorsPro-disclosure factors
Harm/distress from disclosing may cause withdrawal from care and poor healthHarm to others if not disclosed
Disclosing will reduce overall trust in perception of doctorsBenefit to others if information disclosed

Think about the nature of the information and what the patient thinks. Can you minimise the breach of the patient's privacy and still avoid harm?

Genetic medicine introduces another hurdle in relation to confidentiality, because if your patient Is found to have a genetic condition, this might also suggest a probability of this condition in a relative. Many patients share these results with relatives especially if they know it can help to prevent health problems in their relatives. However, if a patient refuses, it would be just to disclose if non-disclosure would risk death or serious harm in others. Try to not disclose patient identity when advising the others of the risks identified to them.

Always document in patient records when disclosing information. Document steps you've taken to seek consent from or inform the patient about the disclosure, or reasons for not doing so.

Whether you can disclose without consent can be complex. Before doing so, seek advice from a Caldicott or data guardian who isn't connected to the reason for the disclosure. Keep the patient details anonymous if possible.

options: Phone your consultant and ask him for advice
Explain that you have discussed the case with your senior, prescibe Anusol and advise him to see his GP tomorrow
Ask the Emergency Department consultant for advice
Phone the GP and politely inform him that it was not an appropriate referral
Phone the registrar back and ask him to review the patient himself
questions:
You are a F2 in general surgery. You have accepted a GP referral for a 25-year-old patient with a one day history of a painful, thrombosed haemorrhoid. On reviewing the patient he does indeed appear to have a 2cm thrombosed haemorrhoid on his left anal margin and is in considerable pain. In the past you have seen similar cases that have benefited from incision and drainage. When you phone the registrar to discuss the case he interrupts you as you are giving the history and calls you 'too soft' for accepting the patient. He tells you to send them home with some Anusol and puts the phone down.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The point of this exam is not to test clinical knowledge. As it happens incision and drainage (under local anaesthetic) is a reasonable management option if a patient presents within 72 hours of haemorrhoids becoming thrombosed. The point really is that given your lack of experience you are not in the best position to determine the management of a patient who is in such considerable pain. Your registrar has not properly listened to the history and simply wants you to 'get rid'.

The best option is to phone the registrar back and as him to see the patient (E). He may be annoyed but he has a responsibility to review any cases his juniors are unsure about. The same applies to the consultant (A). Failing this getting practical advice from an Emergency Department consultant (who will be very experienced in knowing what can be safely/reasonably discharged) is a sensible step (C).

If you choose to discharge the patient (B) then it is sensible to get him to see his GP for follow-up. Telling the GP off about an appropriate referral is a poor option and is unlikely to be well received.

options: Speak to your colleague's consultant on her behalf
Report the consultant to the GMC
Tell your colleague to ignore this
Tell your colleague to discuss this with her consultant
Offer to go with your colleague for her speak to her consultant
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor. A fellow ST1 colleague on a different ward comes to you saying that her consultant makes sexually inappropriate jokes when she is around. She asks you what she should do and asks if it would be possible for you to speak to her consultant on her behalf.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The main themes in this question are those of difficulty with a senior colleague and confidentiality.

Your ST1 colleague is clearly distressed by the consultant making these jokes, and it is therefore appropriate to deal with this situation by your colleague discussing this with him. It is important to know that the consultant might not be aware of the inappropriateness of his jokes, hence it would not be a justified response to escalate the issue. Local resolution should often be the first option in these scenarios. Furthermore, offering to go to speak to the consultant with you colleague may make her feel at ease and by offering to do this you are showing your colleague support. This is why this is the first choice option (5). Advising your colleague to speak to her consultant about the issue (4) is also a correct option, however it does not show your colleague the level of support as option 5.

Speaking to your colleague's consultant on her behalf is the next most appropriate option (1). As your colleague has gave you permission to speak to her consultant on her behalf you would not be breaking confidentiality by doing this. However, you have not witnessed any of the jokes that your colleague is talking about, and if it is to be discussed it should be your colleague that speaks to the consultant about it and not you. Speaking on your colleague's behalf would have negative consequences for the functioning of their medical team and may create animosity between her and the consultant.

Informing the GMC (2) and advising your colleague to ignore the situation (3) are both inappropriate responses to this scenario. Reporting the consultant to the GMC is inappropriate and an excessive response to the scenario. However this is preferable to advising your colleague to ignore the issue as no employee should have to feel uncomfortable in the workplace. This situation needs to be dealt with and having a member of staff suffering in silence is not an option.

options: Attend the scene, but avoid direct patient contact, instructing bystanders to contact 999 and check for a pulse
Phone your medical indemnity provider for advice before assessing the patient further
Avoid any contact with the situation given recent alcohol intake
Ask a bystander to call 999 and start to assess the patient yourself
Call 999 yourself and instruct a bystander on how to check for a pulse
questions:
You are a junior doctor out with friends at a bar. You have had half a pint of beer and are having fun but do not feel drunk. Through the window, you can see that gentleman has collapsed in the street and people around are shouting for help. On arrival one of his friends describes him as 'unconscious' and 'not breathing'.

What is the most appropriate response in this situation?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
In the UK a doctor has no legal obligation to offer assistance in a community situation, however the GMC states you must offer your assistance and give a reasonable level of care. Failing to help at all is unacceptable and may risk your registration.

Despite the fact that you have had a drink, from the stem you are not drunk and functionally impaired when the situation arises. This indicates that you should offer to help in any way you can. The first thing to do is to get someone to phone 999 (D) whilst you assess the patient.

This is better than (E) - as a doctor you are better placed to assess for a pulse than a bystander, even with your direction.

This in turn is better than (A), which involves you taking no direct part other than giving directions.

Phoning your medical indemnity provider (B) is a poor response as they will not realistically be able to give you advice in the required time frame.

Not helping at all (C) is a very poor option. As stated above, you have a professional duty to help where you can.

title: GMC: Good Medical Practice - Maintaining trust
body:
Maintaining trust is one of the four domains in Good Medical Practice.

Key points include
  • Show respect for patients
  • Treat patients and colleagues fairly and without discrimination
  • Act with honesty and integrity

Please see the link for more details.

options: Take some anti-depressant medication
See your GP
Consult the GMC guidance on reporting changes to health
Obtain support from close family
Consult the NICE guidance on reporting changes to health
Take annual leave
Request to change rotations
Do nothing
questions:
You are a junior doctor about to start your last rotation of the year in renal medicine. Over the preceding few weeks you have noticed that your mood has been low. Your concentration while at work is poor and you find yourself tired and stressed for most of the day. This is starting to have an effect on the quality of your work and you have called in sick on more than one occasion which has not seemed to help. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
The GMC recommends that if you have a change in your physical or mental health then you should obtain advice from a registered healthcare professional. In this situation the most appropriate is likely to be your GP. The GMC has guidance on its website of what should be disclosed to them when thinking about health problems. It is often not much about the condition itself, but how it impacts on your ability to work. Having supportive family, friends and colleagues who you can confide in is always useful. However, you may not always feel able to tell them about problems such as this.

NICE are not involved in this kind of problem. Taking time off in some situations may help, but not in this one. You should not self-prescribe. The best thing to do is get healthcare advice from another doctor, ideally the GP. Doing nothing and leaving the Foundation Programme is avoiding the problem.

title: GMC guidance: doctor's health
body:
The General Medical Council (GMC) makes it explicitly clear that you should not rely on your own judgement of the risk posed by your health to your patients. They state that this should be done by an 'appropriately qualified healthcare professional'. You must seek and follow their advice on any changes to your work necessary. In this case therefore, the only appropriate choice is to consult occupational health.

Risks posed to patients by your own health
  • 'If you know or suspect that you have a serious condition that you could pass on to patients, or if your judgement or performance could be affected by a condition or its treatment, you must consult a suitably qualified colleague.'
  • 'You must follow their advice about any changes to your practice they consider necessary.'
  • 'You must not rely on your own assessment of the risk to patients.'

Good Medical Practice, domain 2, subsections 28-30, GMC 2013
concept: You should seek medical advice and report any changes to your health which may affect your ability to work

Tell them you don't feel it is appropriate in a work environment and close the door behind you
Say nothing and close the door behind you
Tell the practice manager and let him/her take appropriate action

questions:
You are a GP registrar. On walking into a consulting room during work hours you catch the married F2 doctor and a receptionist kissing.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This behaviour is inappropriate in a work environment. The best approach would be to voice your concerns directly (B).

The next best option would be to inform the practice manager - part of their role covers human resource and staffing issues such as this (D).

Doing nothing does not address the issue (C).

Significant event forms (A) were not designed for this kind of scenario.

Calling the F2 doctor's wife (E) is a poor option as it is likely to result in considerable disharmony in the surgery.

questions:
You are a junior doctor on a GP rotation. A patient presents with rectal bleeding and tenesmus. During the rectal examination you notice an irregular, firm lesion on the rectal mucosa. You plan to make a fast-track referral to the colorectal surgeons.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
It can be difficult dealing with suspicions of cancer. On one hand, there is no confirmation of the diagnosis and you don't want to unduly alarm the patient. On the other hand, it may be an opportunity to give a 'warning shot' and the patient may feel let down if you avoided the issue altogether if they are eventually diagnosed with cancer.

Whilst opinions will vary (as will the patient and situation) it seems that the most appropriate response is to give a warning shot to the patient. Although it is likely that the examination findings represent a malignancy immediately telling a patient without confirmation is not the best response.

Option B is vague and not best practice as the patient will clearly understand the implications of being told to take a family member along. If you want to give a warning shot, it's better to do it in a more standard and direct way.

Option E involves a degree of withholding information which is poor practice. Furthermore, the specialist doctor is likely to mention the reason for referral when the patient attends the clinic.

Withholding or lying about the examination findings (C) is unprofessional and likely to damage your long-term relationship with the patient.
